Name: Nigel Huddleston MP
Message: In PMQs today, I asked the Prime Minister to confirm that it is her intention to go further than Dame Judith Hackitt's recommendations on building safety regulations and ban inflamable cladding, so that we avoid a horrific tragedy like Grenfell ever happening again. I was delighted that the Prime Minister confirmed that the Government is minded to go further than the recommendations and ban all combustible materials in cladding on high rise buildings.

Name: Paul Scully MP
Message: Yesterday I had another opportunity to pay tribute to the Grenfell Speaks campaigners and talk about the need to ensure we act, not just say soothing words, to ensure the community get the housing and the justice they need and deserve.

Name: Tom Pursglove MP
Message: Last Tuesday, I went to a drop-in session at Speaker’s House organised by Grenfell United. This was a very useful opportunity to get an update on the current situation, but also to meet and talk to survivors about their individual experiences, particularly given the parliamentary debate which is to take place next week. The conversations were extremely difficult and very, very, moving, but an important opportunity for us as MPs to get the direct feedback of those so tragically affected, and make sure we are doing everything we possibly can to help them rebuild their lives and ensure a tragedy like this can never happen again. Photography by Marley Edwards.

Name: Paul Scully MP
Message: In my opening speech during the Grenfell Inquiry debate, I read out the names of the 72 victims of the fire to show that this isn't about process but people. The Prime Minister has shown that she is listening by appointing two additional panel members but we need to do more to meet the needs and expectations of Grenfell Speaks. They feel ignored, forgotten about and that the establishment treats them as a bother. It isn't the case but the belief is totally understandable. The government at every level, national and local, needs to continue to work hard to ensure that the survivors can get answers, start to rebuild their lives and see justice done.

Name: Paul Scully MP
Message: Yesterday was a tough but rewarding day. I led the debate in Parliament about the #Grenfell Inquiry. Grenfell Speaks were out in Parliament Square beforehand to express their frustration, despair and anger and of course to pay tribute to the 72 victims of the fire. Reading some of the pen sketches about the victims in preparation for my speech was so moving and really hammered home the need to ensure that every part of the rehousing and recovery process is people-centred. I'm really grateful to Grenfell United and members of the community to take the time to speak to me and I value their dignified determination and resolve.

Name: Sir Peter Bottomley MP
Message: Last week the All-Party Group on Leasehold and Commonhold Reform, to which I am Co-chair, held a highly successful meeting with over 80 attendees from within the leasehold sector including the legal profession and many of my colleagues from across Parliament. Speakers included John Hall, Director at the Ministry of Housing Communities and Local Government, who updated MPs and leasehold sector insiders on government action to outlaw leasehold houses and reduce ground rents to as low as zero. Law Commissioner Professor Nicholas Hopkins outlined progress on his review of leasehold enfranchisement and extension, and commonhold. After the meeting there was a drinks reception to celebrate the achievements of the Leasehold Knowledge Partnership, which is also the secretariat of the APPG, in finally getting leasehold reform onto the government’s agenda. We are making progress, none of which would have been possible without the hard work of many individuals and groups who are uniting for...

Name: Sir Peter Bottomley MP
Message: Earlier this week I welcomed the new Secretary of State for Housing, Communities, and Local Governments, James Brokenshire MP, and stressed the importance that he continue the work begun by his predecessor, Sajid Javid, had achieved in further fighting for the rights of leaseholders across the country. Following the tragedy of Grenfell Tower, it is more important than ever that we ensure dangerous cladding is removed post-haste, with the financial implications borne by those responsible for its use rather than those it was imposed on. The Secretary of States' response was highly receptive and signals that, as I would hope, he will continue to work alongside myself, my Parliamentary colleagues, and Leasehold Knowledge Partnership, in furthering the work to the protect endangered lives of leaseholders across this country.

Name: Chris Philp
Message: The Government has successfully persuaded the housing development company Barratt Developments to fund the recladding of Citiscape. The cladding of Citiscape, two blocks of flats on the corner of Frith and Drummond Road, was deemed to be a fire safety risk following the Grenfell tragedy – with residents told that they would have to pay for the recladding. The cost of recladding an improving fire safety were expected to cost leaseholders between £5,000 to £6,000 per flat. The two tower blocks, which are ten and six storeys tall respectively contain 97 flats, with the exterior covered in a cladding material deemed unsafe following the Grenfell tragedy. Sajid Javid, the Secretary of State for Housing, Communities and Local Government, announced the decision via Twitter, stating: “Delighted Barratt Developments have told residents of the #Citiscape flats they will cover fire safety and cladding costs. This is the right thing to do and I want to see others follow their lead to protect...

Name: Derek Thomas
Message: Which? End Dangerous Products Campaign I welcome the latest Which? Magazine’s new campaign to ‘End Dangerous Products’ in the home. According to their investigation, faulty white goods such as washing machines, tumble dryers and fridge freezers cause more than 60 house fires a week, a truly shocking statistic. Indeed a fridge freezer started the horrific and tragic Grenfell Tower fire, although it is not yet clear whether the manufacturer was at fault. I have been aware of the fire hazards that such household goods present for a while through a charity called Electricity Safety First which works to ensure that everyone in the UK understands the importance of electrical safety and that this remains a priority for consumers, trade and government. Over the past couple of years I have organised several Winter Wellbeing and Health events in the constituency when a team from Electricity Safety First has been on hand to offer sensible, down-to-earth advice about their electric appliances...

Name: Chris Green
Message: My latest column for the Leigh Observer is below. You can read my next one in this week's paper, which is out now. I would like to wish you all a very happy New Year. As we begin 2018, it is natural to look back on the year we have had – and what a year of ups and downs 2017 has been. I think when we look back on 2017 in years to come, we will remember the horrific terror attacks which shook our country – including one right on our doorsteps at Manchester Arena. We will never forget the images we saw and the stories we read of these awful attacks and we will never forget the families who lost children and parents. It is difficult to imagine that they will have just spent their first Christmas without their loved ones. At least nine terror attacks have been foiled by police and security services in our country this year. It is right that the government has increased the police’s counter terrorism budget by 7 percent, with a £50 million increase taking it to at least £757 million....

Name: Helen Whately
Message: This New Year I want to say a big thank you to our incredible emergency services and first responders. Most of us look forward to a few days off at Christmas, but for people who work in A&Es, ambulance services, the police, NHS 111, mental health crisis teams and volunteers with charities like Age UK and the Samaritans, the work continues. With Grenfell Tower, the Manchester bombing, disgraceful attacks on Westminster and London Bridge - Britain has suffered too many terrible tragedies this year. But we have come through. That we are still standing firm and looking forward to a better future is only possible thanks to the incredible bravery and hard work of the emergency and security services. Not only have they responded to terrible attacks, they have also prevented them. I pay particular tribute to the police and others who kept me, my colleagues and staff safe during the Westminster attack, even as they were grieving for the loss of one of their own: PC Keith Palmer. I hope that...

Name: Grant Shapps MP
Message: They say a week's a long time in politics, so a year must seem like an eternity. Who could have foreseen a year ago that unexpected General Election, those shocking terrorist attacks on London & Manchester and the sheer human suffering of Grenfell Tower? As ever, it's been a year of contrasts. Locally, we have seen some good outcomes, like the re-opening of the Post Office in Welwyn Garden City and continued record falls in unemployment; meaning more people have jobs than ever before in our area. And, as we look to 2018, there's much more to be done here in Welwyn Hatfield. So I'll be launching the 'Make Healthcare Local' campaign, to try and convince health bosses that, with a growing population, we need more health services in our community; rather than miles away. And I'll be campaigning for the widening of the A1M Motorway, with 'Smart running' to reduce the queues at rush hour. But, of course, some of the most significant events of 2018 will also be the hardest to predict. So...

Name: Theresa May
Message: As we gather with our friends and family, I want to say thank you to all those whose service to others means they will be spending time away from their loved ones this Christmas. Men and women in our armed forces whose humbling bravery and daily sacrifices help to ensure the security of our nation and our allies around the world. The heroes in our emergency services whose courage and dedication so inspired the nation in response to tragedy at Grenfell Tower and the abhorrent terrorist attacks in Manchester and London. But whose service saves lives in our communities every day, including Christmas Day. And the thousands of volunteers in our country who will give up their time to make someone else’s Christmas that little bit better: from faith inspired projects like the Churches Together initiative in my own constituency - to aid workers helping those in war-torn parts of the world. As we celebrate the birth of Christ, let us celebrate all those selfless acts - and countless others -...

The lessons of this tragedy must be learnt, as this can never be allowed to happen again - and, particularly at this time of year, we pause to think of all those affected by this dreadful tragedy. Name: Nick Boles MP
Message: Great to discuss my ideas for a Square Deal on housing with Tim Montgomerie at Policy Exchange.
Description:
Britain is in the grip of a housing crisis. 

As part of his series on how the Conservatives can recapture the initiative, Nick Boles MP – former Director of Policy Exchange, former Minister for Planning and Minister for Skills, and author of www.squaredeal.org.uk – has written on how the Government can build the number of homes needed. He urges the development of a ‘Grenfell Housing Commission’ to build 500,000 affordable homes in 10 years – funded by a ‘Grenfell bond’; requiring developers to speed up development on sites where they have planning permission; and reform of the housing market, including increasing the number of suppliers. Here he is in conversation with Tim Montgomerie, founder of UnHerd.

Name: Kelly Tolhurst
Message: The disaster at Grenfell Tower was deeply upsetting and will change social housing forever once we have the answers to many searching questions. No doubt, without the bravery and determination of our fire and rescue services we could have been facing many more deaths but it is clear that it should not come down to this in the first place. I have been in contact with local social landlord mhs homes to clarify the safety standards of our local high rises and I welcome the improvements that have been made over the past year and beyond and I am relieved that no cladding is used on any of their buildings. Name: Justin Tomlinson
Message: I joined the Fire Service and Clls last week to visit the high rise towers in Penhill to reassure residents that in the wake of the tragic fire at Grenfell Tower, their buildings are completely up to fire safety standards and there is no reason to worry. Residents have been assured that the high rise buildings in the area are completely brick cladded and lack any combustible cladding, such as composite aluminium cladding that was seen in the tragedy at Grenfell Tower. Message: In Parliament this morning, MPs expressed their horror about the Grenfell fire and I had the chance to ask the Prime Minister a question. People living in high-rise buildings in Barnet will be worried about fire safety after these terrible events. I urged Barnet Council to take action and I welcome the work they are undertaking to re-examine fire safety in high-rise blocks to find out whether any of the problems which contributed to the Grenfell disaster are present in Barnet. Name: Damian Collins
Message: The Tragedy at Grenfell Tower The Grenfell Tower fire in North Kensington in London will surely been seen as one of the greatest civil disasters in this country since the Second World War. Alongside other disasters like Hillsborough and Aberfan, it was tragic both for the large loss and life, and because it was avoidable. A full public inquiry will establish the exact cause of the fire, but we know that there have been warnings about the risk of fire in tower blocks like these, the need for sprinklers systems, and concerns raised about certain types of building cladding that may be more vulnerable to fire. It is not enough however to say that lessons will be learnt and that the appropriate fire safety measures will be retrofitted into other blocks that may have a similar risk to Grenfell tower. These are good values for a politician to hold dear, and I'll go on doing so. Now for Wednesday and the Queen's Speech (programme of new laws). Name: James Cleverly
Message: Voting against the "Homes fit for Human Habitation Bill because I am a Landlord" - Nice meme, but it isn't true. In response the the terrible fire and loss of life at Grenfell Tower a number of people have criticised me for voting against Labour's "Homes Fit For Human Habitation Bill". They highlight my parliamentary declaration of interests showing that I was a private landlord and imply (or state) that I did so out of financial self interest. Almost every element of those accusations is untrue. I don't usually respond to baseless accusations but this one is particularly pernicious and is being linked to the tragedy at Grenfell Tower. So in this instance I think it deserves a response. The bill that I am accused of voting down was in fact a Labour amendment to the government's Housing and Planning Bill. The amendment tried to bring in some clauses from a private member's bill that failed to make progress, as is the case with the vast majority of private member's bills. I voted...

Name: James Cleverly
Message: Grenfell Tower fire Like many people I have been shocked and saddened beyond measure by the terrible fire in Grenfell Tower. The loss of so many lives in such a horrific way is numbing. I have paused before commenting because of there has been a huge amount of speculation on social media and in the mainstream media, I didn't want to add to that. The Prime Minister was right to call for an enquiry to run in parallel with the fire service investigation. Clearly something (or things) went very badly wrong and we need to find out promptly what happened in case emergency remedial action needs to be taken in other similar high rise buildings. As you can see from the Prime Minister's letter to MPs the government has put in place an action plan to help those affected by the fire and also ensure we are able to protect other residents of tall buildings.

Name: Matt Warman MP
Message: Following the Grenfell Tower tragedy in London a number of constituents have asked me for reassurance about the cladding on Boston's Pilgrim Hospital. I have been assured it is made of rockwool, and is therefore not a risk. I have provided private reassurance to people who have asked, and hope this public statement is helpful. I'd like to thank ULHT for proactively providing me with this information.

We were all open-mouthed in horror at the dreadful scenes that unfolded and overcome with sympathy and support for the survivors and those who have lost loved ones. Name: Tom Tugendhat
Message: Tonight many Muslims in London will be preparing for iftar, the meal that breaks the Ramadan fast. Traditionally it is a time for celebration when family and friends gather. After mosques and churches have been collecting for those lost everything in the Grenfell Tower it will be more muted. The death of Mohammed al-Haj Ali who fled the war in Syria and the loss of the el-Wahabi family, the final calls home from Marco Gottardi and his girlfriend Gloria Trevisan, both architects from the Veneto region of northern Italy, will be in the minds of many. This tragedy has exposed failings in our society. Not one that affects only the poor or only the rich, but all of us. We are all hurt by this tragedy and must find out what happened and stop it ever happening again. It's also why we must open criminal proceedings and be ready to prosecute those whose failings led to this terrible fire. Name: Steve Double MP
Message: Thoughts with those caught in the tragic events at Grenfell Tower. My thoughts and prayers are with those affected and their families as well as our emergency services. Following the fire I have been in touch with management of Ocean Housing to seek reassurances regarding Park House Flats in St Austell. St Austell Fire Station and Ocean Housing are holding an Q&A event on Tuesday that I would encourage people with concerns to attend. The details are below: https://www.facebook.com/StAustellFireStation/posts/1974774532752222:0
Description:
Following the tragic fire in London, we want to reassure the public and those who are concerned about fire safety. We will be joining Ocean Housing at Park House flats between 9 am and 12 noon on Tuesday, 20 June to answer questions and provide reassurance to residents. Fire safety officers will be available for specialist advice and operational crews will be offering home fire safety checks.

For further fire safety help and advice, visit our website: www.cornwall.gov.uk/fire or www.cornwall.gov.uk/fireflats or call us on 0800 3581 999 (24 hours).

Name: Richard Graham
Message: A new term starts: walking with Dr Caroline Johnson to the Lords for the authorisation of a new Parliament. The Queen's Speech setting out the legislative programme is on Wednesday. I expect a Mental Health Bill & work towards resolving the thorny question of social care - and that much of the focus of other legislation will be around leaving the EU. The dynamics of every Parliament change. This one has more diversity and (I anticipate) less stridency from the SNP: and perhaps more co-operation across party boundaries on selected issues, which I'd welcome. Meanwhile we await the investigation into the awful Grenfell Tower inferno, and both that and the tasering and arrest of a man with a knife outside Parliament reminds us that life is to be treasured.

Name: Dame Caroline Spelman MP
Message: Earlier today Councillor Ken Hawkins, Solihull Council Cabinet Member for Housing, and I visited some of the tower blocks in Chelmsley Wood to inspect the condition of cladding. Following regular correspondence with the local council and Solihull Community Housing as well as a meeting today with them, I have been advised that all of the necessary checks have been carried out to ensure that strictest fire regulations are met in all blocks and that the materials used to clad the facade of the building are not the same as those used in the case of Grenfell Tower in London. Further, that SCH's neighbourhood officers have been out visiting local residents and distributing literature to reassure tenants of the efforts being taken to ensure their safety.

Name: Theresa Villiers
Message: The Grenfell Tower disaster is truly shocking. I welcome the decision to set up a full public inquiry to establish what happened and ensure we do everything we can to prevent such a tragedy from ever occurring again. I agree with the Mayor of London that the inquiry should produce an interim report as soon as possible. I have been in touch with the Barnet Council to stress the importance of immediate action to establish whether any buildings in Barnet suffer from the same problems which appear to have played a part in the Grenfell fire. Whilst we cannot yet be certain of what the causes of the fire were, every effort should be made right away to make people as safe as possible in their homes, and Barnet Homes and Barnet Council are already taking action. I send my deepest condolences to all those families who have lost loved ones. My sympathies also go to victims who have been injured and to everyone who has lost their home.

Name: Royston Smith MP
Message: In recent days, I have been contacted by a number of residents, some by email and others on Facebook, in relation to an Independent article from last year linked to the 2016 Housing and Planning Act. The tragic incident at Grenfell is in all of our minds currently and all of my thoughts go out to those involved, the victims and their families. Without question, what unfolded at Grenfell should never have happened and a comprehensive review and investigation is needed to understand what went on and lessons will need to be learned. Following this incident, I have been surprised by the immediate move by some to politicise this terrible incident and the lives lost. Many people have linked a parliamentary vote in 2016, which I voted on, as an indication of blame for Grenfell. The Independent who published this article last year, have confirmed in a subsequent article yesterday, that the vote on an amendment in 2016 as part of the Housing and Planning Act, would have had no impact on...

Message: Well the B&R Blog is Back! It has been a very interesting week since the 2017 General Election. What ever the reason and whatever the result - We are where we are!!! For all followers of politics you can find out what has been happening in Westminster from any news bulletin or newspaper but I hope to tell you in my blogs how it is behind the press reports for an active Member of Parliament. For an MP of two years standing it is a strange feeling coming back to Westminster to resume your duties as an MP. The route to London is the same, the Palace of Westminster looks the same, and the staff are the same. But you find that you are no longer the new boy and there are 80 something newbies and you have become part of the old guard. This week has been full of congratulations and commiserations - pleased to see so many colleagues back with several having now been made ministers. Name: Dame Caroline Spelman MP
Message: I was shocked and saddened to learn of the massive blaze which engulfed Grenfell Tower in London in the early hours of yesterday morning and which has led to a significant loss of life. At this time our thoughts and prayers must be with the victims, their families and loved ones, and with the emergency services who responded so rapidly and so courageously to this incident. In the past 24 hours I have been contacted by local residents who have expressed their concerns about the high rise blocks in our borough which have undergone renovation in recent years. I have received assurances from Solihull Community Housing and the local authority that they work closely with the fire service, carry out regular risk assessments and are 'extremely aware' of what they as building managers need to do to ensure the safety of local residents at all times in case of a fire. I understand that more detailed information from SCH will be coming forward to local residents and I would urge any concerned...

Name: Alex Chalk
Message: Following the dreadful tragedy at Grenfell Tower in London I have today spoken to Gloucestershire's Chief Fire Officer to seek urgent reassurance about all high-rise buildings in Cheltenham. I am advised that fire crews have now visited all our relevant buildings. They have carried out further risk assessments and provided reassurance to local residents. I am assured that there is no cause for concern and that the buildings are safe. Government Ministers also gave instructions that checks should be carried out on every high rise with similar cladding to that at Grenfell Tower. None are affected in Gloucestershire. Meanwhile, I attended a briefing in Parliament from ministers this afternoon, and the Prime Minister has ordered a full public inquiry. No stone must be left unturned in getting to the bottom of what happened in Grenfell Tower. My thoughts are with all those affected by this horrific incident.

Name: Julian Smith MP
Message: I am deeply shocked and saddened by the fire at Grenfell Tower. My thoughts are with those affected and their friends and family. The Government is committed to a full public inquiry into this terrible incident and the Government will make a statement shortly.

Name: Mims Davies
Message: Thank you for contacting me both here, on email and twitter about the truly tragic events at Grenfell Towers on Wednesday morning. Like you, I was devastated when I first heard of the tragedy that was unfolding in Kensington, and join the Prime Minister and others in giving my heartfelt condolences to the families and friends of those that lost their lives. This is a truly awful situation with much uncertainty still for many families, friends & colleagues and it is a really heartbreaking situation. The immediate focus must be to ensure that those that now find themselves homeless have shelter and support going forward, many of them having lost all of their worldly possessions. I would also like to acknowledge the amazing efforts of our emergency services, who as always went beyond the call of duty, and as a result, saved countless lives. Name: Robin Walker MP
Message: Worcester’s MP, Robin Walker, has expressed his condolences to all those affected by the fire at Grenfell Tower in West London. In the early hours of this morning (14th June) over 200 fire fighters from London Fire Brigade attended a rapidly developing incident at the 24-storey tower block in North Kensington. The fire was quickly declared a major incident and crews wearing breathing apparatus have been working in extremely difficult conditions to rescue people and bring this major fire under control.
